message_1: A steel pipe with a diameter of 5 cm and a length of 2m is filled with water. The pipe is clamped at one end and left free at the other end. A harmonic pressure of 1 kPa is applied to the free end of the pipe with a frequency of 50 Hz. Calculate the natural frequency of the pipe-water system and determine if resonance occurs.
message_2:
To calculate the natural frequency of the pipe-water system, we need to consider the speed of sound in water and the length of the pipe. The speed of sound in water is approximately 1500 m/s. Since the pipe is clamped at one end and free at the other end, it will have a quarter-wavelength resonance condition.

The formula for the natural frequency (f) of the pipe-water system is:

f = (v / 4L)

where v is the speed of sound in water (1500 m/s) and L is the length of the pipe (2 m).

f = (1500 m/s) / (4 * 2 m)
f = 1500 m/s / 8 m
f = 187.5 Hz

The natural frequency of the pipe-water system is 187.5 Hz.

Now, we need to determine if resonance occurs. Resonance occurs when the applied frequency is equal to or very close to the natural frequency of the system. In this case, the applied frequency is 50 Hz, which is not equal to or very close to the natural frequency of 187.5 Hz.

Therefore, resonance does not occur in this pipe-water system.
